comments.commentBody: Governor Walker lives in La La Land.  the reason that the Feds got involve in social programs was and is that the states, especially the "Red States" have ignored the needs of their citizens for decades. In those states without government aid programs, wages are lower, the poverty rate is higher, the citizens are sicker and more die earlier than in the progressive states that help their citizens.

Gov. Walker argues for a return to the Article of Confederation. A time in American history when a weak central government failed to unify the states securely. We forget that the period of Mar 1, 1781, to Sept 13, 1788, was one of turmoil and enmity between our citizens.

Our first experiment in self-governance failed because states would act without consideration of the United States and this undermined our new union's ability to be unified in trade and international treaties. Each state set up economic interests in competition with other states. Our government money became the subject of the popular derision, "not worth a Continental." Interstate commerce failed in the absence of a strong central government.

Gov. Walker and his GOP brethren yearn for a return to days of anti-Federalism. They look forward to destroying our Constitution and the establishment of unified policy among our states. One that was novel in history, as Madison presented in Federalist 39: "The constitutional reallocation of powers created a new form of government, unprecedented under the sun. Every previous national authority either had been centralized or else had been a confederation of sovereign states. The new American system was neither one nor the other; it was a mixture of both."

Walker's call for more block grants is code for taking the collective efforts of the states in funding and stripping the unifying guidance that creates confidence in uniform administration across our United States.

On the contrary, Mr. Walker has left Wisconsin in shambles, as I saw firsthand while traveling across the state last summer. Wisconsin is largely destitute, aside from a few narrow corridors of concentrated wealth (where Mr. Walker's supporters reside). The most talented educators have fled to greener pastures. Wisconsin, a once lovely, noble, and sensible state, has become Kansas.

What Mr. Walker fails to grasp, among numerous other things, is that the political and personal discomfort he's experienced, and which his Republican colleagues have experienced, has only just begun. He may wish to take another antacid and think twice about showing his face in the public square.

Drug testing welfare recipients has been proven to be nothing but a huge expense to taxpayers. Such programs play to some voters' beliefs that welfare recipients are drug addicts looking for a free ride, but this has repeatedly been found to not be the case.

In making his case that ACA should be reversed and that healthcare responsibility should be returned to the states, Governor Walker conveniently ignores that Obamacare was intended to be a partnership between the states and the federal government. It was an effort to even out the discrepancies between states to empower them with the ability to run their own programs on a more even ground. Republican governors like Walker rejected the assistance that would help them do that. In making such a 'states rights' argument, they would have us be a nation where some states exist in the First World and others in the Third, which would not really be much of a nation.

Gov. Walker recommends that Republicans "stand strong against" protestors and liberals. It seems to me that if millions of his fellow Americans are regularly protesting, they might have a legitimate beef. Rather than standing against them, which only polarizes an alrealdy divided nation even more, he might be better advised to engage with these people and actually listen to their concerns in an effort to seek consensus and solutions everyone can live with. Surely the people are better served by elected officials who "stand strong against" an us-&-them mentality.

Scott Walker's biggest legacy as the governor will be the dismantling of one of the greatest research universities in the world: University of Wisconsin, Madison. Under Walker's leadership, the systematic divestment in public education, public health, and public infrastructure has nudged one of the most dynamic and progressive states into a free fall in most metrics of economic and social well being. In 2016, Wisconsin--the once shining example of Midwestern can-do spirit--voted like a poor, Southern state. Walker's fiscal austerity has been a giveaway to a handful of corporations and political donors, but it was eviscerated the middle class and those precious institutions whose job it is to make sure that  ordinary Wisconsinites thrive and succeed. Scott Walker sold out middle class in his state in a cynical move to curry favors from the GOP establishment for his 2016 presidential run--well, how did that turn out?

The outcome of the Presidential election was far from a clear mandate. Only a partisan, smooth talking to cover his real agenda back stabber like Scott Walker would say so. The Repbulican Agenda is to help the wealthy keep as much of there money as possible, and to screw everybody else. The Republican Agenda might be good for business but people remember, so was slavery and a free hand to polite the environment. He sounds nice, but that's to fool people into thinking he isn't robbing them blind. He's a smiling back-stabber. If the heart of the Republican agenda is to return power to the States, then the heart of their agenda is to encourage inequality, inconsistent services, weakened environmental protection, weakened education, weakened support for science, in the end a collection of second rate places called "States".

Not to worry.  When Ryan's budget axes funding for food stamps, CHIPs etc. the drug testing won't be necessary.  But  maybe before sports team owners get any more taxpayer provided stadiums, they should be drug tested.  My observation have been in my 77 years that there are just as many very wealthy and successful people using cocaine and marijuana as poor people.  The wealthy are not as likely to use meth or heroin, but there are always exceptions.  The daughter of one of the couples living in my gated community and her centi-millionaire husband  died of heroin overdoses in their London townhouse several years back!

Most of the red states' taxpayers get far more than pennies on their federal tax dollars.  It's the blue states that get less.  By all means, return control to the states.  Let them try to run their own programs.  But as a part of this, the flow of federal dollars to these states must end.  Let's see how long it takes before the red states come pleading for federal governance and money.  The federal government controls a lot, but it also pays for a lot.  Returning control to the states must have its cost; the red states cannot have both state control and federal money.  I am certain that the red states will not be willing to give up the huge and grotesquely unfair subsidies they receive from states like Connecticut.  To quote from President Bartlett, speaking of the federal money Florida received:  "Can we have it back, please?"

Yes, give power to the states like in Louisiana where pollution is killing the waters and people. There people are willing to kill themselves and the things they love to have a job to keep their version of the American dream alive. To do this the state and local governments have to look the other way and actively deny that they're killing the environment.

That is not what I want. I do not want the state governments to make poor decisions for people that live int heir states and I don't want the states to make decisions that ultimately affect all Americans.

It is proven that states that make poor decisions have worse outcomes. It is also proven that in general liberal states fare better overall than conservative states.

This all sounds like a lot of men on steroids: shred the social programs that help families, elderly and the poor; build more aircraft carriers (war is actually obsolete as it is unproductive - economic advances are what count) and build a wall (are we going to give the Rio Grande to Mexico?)?
It is much better to improve the things that are a measure of society: health, education, quality of life, the arts, science, sports, parks and nature. We don't have enough money for both hate and love.

Return things to the states?  The same states that discriminated against African-Americans until the Federal Government forced them not to?   The same states that continue to countenance gender discrimination?   The same states with cretin governors who think that rape is a choice?  The same states which have been complicit in denying their citizens access to decent healthcare in the first place?   I think not Scott.

How trite.

Returning power to the state means each state sets up its medical program. The variance in those programs will of course be toward the denial, lack of access, and too expensive for most persons type of policy.

That is what we had before Obamacare and that is what we would get with this Trump-care: junk and making America sick again.

Phony capitalism and fake democracy is what Scott Walker has always stood for.

Having finally won the right to occupy the White House for the next four years coupled with occupying about 60% of state executive mansions and legislatures why should Republicans change their basic tenor and tone towards health care?

Led by lifelong government health care welfare dole king Paul Ryan along with political lawyer party hack White House Chief of Staff Reince Preibus and mis-governor Scott Walker, the great state of Wisconsin is no longer a Democratic People's Republic.

Instead it is more like a colony of the Roman or British Empire or the Thousand Year Third Reich. Hillary lost Wisconsin to this trio. And while 95% of black women voted Clinton about 54% of white women voted Trump along with 58% of white voters.
Wait, we won the popular vote by about 3 million. So we will continue to show up and ask our representatives and senators to show up also.

No, Gov. Walker, millions more people voted for "Washington."

Those "pennies on the dollar"? Conservative states tend to get more than 100 of those pennies on each of their dollars.

Which states have different needs for health care? I thought everyone needs it.

And let's not forget the obscene decisions by states not to accept Medicaid coverage from the ACA.

@njglea
All the liberal drum circles and poetry slams in the world will not stop the dangerous slope we are headed for- The GOP sold out their own people to achieve their Christian manifest destiny. I once read that democracies have a life expectancy of 250 years until it implodes and that is exactly what is happening now.

Lets put all the distractions aside and focus on the point here, "the protesters should not be listened to."

The protesters are mostly those who voted for the loser in the election, or did not vote. So just because the losers are screaming, why listen? The winner should do what he said he would do. Just because someone who voted for the loser is now protesting, why should the winner not do what his voters voted for?

The losers need to get over their loss. Instead of yelling about the other side winning, get your candidate elected. Losing and yelling helps no one.

Last, before being impressed by protests in many areas, remember the saying, show me a bad loser and I'll show you a loser.
The 1% are doing very well in Wisconsin, so, in that sense, Walker has succeeded.
Scott's neo-confederate economic policy has made Wisconsin into a state where no one chooses to live, right down there with Kansas.

Luettgen actually makes sense for once, twice!
Not much better than a stopped clock, yet, but at least he stops Walker at state's rights to selectively deny healthcare.

Amen.

The bait and switch of the American citizen's basic rights to express political discontent and Walker labeling peaceful protest as "intimidation" needs to be highlighted.

Drug testing benefit recipients serves two functions:

It makes it harder and more demeaning to obtain the benefits.

It puts money into the hands of cronies who just happen to own labs that get government contracts to test applicants...

You are correct. If as an example California sent the same amount of Fed Tax dollars per capita as Alabama or Kentucky etc. ( to Washington) and kept the rest for their own schools etc. the southern states will go broke and California would be able to pay off it's own debt. Scott Walker has not thought this trough!
I further believe the senators from the South, and their Governors, ought to balance their own budget before they demand that DC balance the Fed Budget.
